01

Contents:
For years and years, as men sailed
over the oceans,
everything that lay
very far beneath the surface was a
mystery.
Some sailors thought giant
sea dragons swam through the ocean
depths.
They thought these dragons
came up now and then to gobble down
a ship, sailors and all!
Other sailors
believed in mermaids－beautiful
women who had tails like fish instead
of legs.
2

 color: rgb(76,76,76);
}

Contents:
Ocean legends told about a creature
that was half woman and half bird.
Supposedly, many of these creatures,
called sirens, sat on rocky reefs and
sang songs.
They sang so sweetly that
sailors on ships tried to reach them
but crashed into the rocks.
These ideas
of the early sailors seem silly to us
now
because we know a lot more
about what’s in the underwater world.
4

Contents:
Today men go far below the surface
of the ocean not only to explore but
to live.
This aquanaut, named John,
breathing air from his aqualung,
is
hundreds of feet below the surface
of the ocean.
He is so far down that
even though it is daytime at the
surface, it is dark down here.
6

Contents:
On the surface it is a windy, stormy
day.
But down here it is calm.
John
moves along slowly, stopping to pick
up a few rock samples, which he puts
into his basket.
You might think he’d
be worried about the storm above,
but he’s not.
His home right now is
here on the ocean bottom.
And here
the wind cannot reach him.
He swims
under the strange-looking sea house
and grabs hold of a ladder.
7

Contents:
He climbs up the ladder and enters
the sea house through an open hole.
The sea house is filled with a specially
mixed air.
John takes off his skintight
underwater suit and dries off with a
towel.
Then he sits down at the table
for a cup of hot coffee and a ham and
cheese sandwich.
And all the time
he’s still underwater.
8

Contents:
“They’re having quite a storm upstairs,”
says one of the other aquanauts, who
is wearing earphones.
He is talking to
the radio operator on the mother ship
－the ship at the surface.
Behind John, on the lower bunk,
another aquanaut is snoring.
He was
out collecting sea plants and rocks all
morning, and now he is taking a nap.
Doctor’s orders.
9

Contents:
As soon as John
has finished
eating, it will be
time for his daily
checkup.
The
doctor lives in the
sea house with the aquanauts so that he
can keep an eye on them.
After supper, before going to bed, each
aquanaut writes down what he did that
day.
He puts labels on the things he
found and collected.
Then he may play
a game of checkers.
10

 color: rgb(255,255,255);
}

Contents:
The first men to live underwater were
studied carefully
to discover whether
living on the ocean bottom did
anything to their health.
Scientists
wanted to find out
how much work it
was safe for them to do
and how much
they had to sleep or rest.
11

Contents:
For men to live underwater and keep
the “door” to their sea house open so
that they can go in and out,
the
specially mixed air must be squeezed
so that it pushes against the water in
the doorway to keep the water from
flooding the room.
12

<style type="text/css" >

 color: rgb(255,255,255);
}

Contents:
The water presses very hard because
the weight of all the water above is
pressing down, too.
Because of all this
water pressure, people thought that
men could never go very far below
the surface of the water and live.
They thought that the men would be
crushed.
But ways have been found
for aquanauts to stay at great depths
and live.
13

Contents:
A man living underwater may have
strange helpers.
In one experiment, an
aquanaut swims away from the sea
house until he is “lost.”
He pretends
to be in trouble.
He waits in the wet
darkness.
Then he feels something
touching him softly.
It is one of the
aquanaut’s best helpers－a dolphin
－coming to the rescue.
14

Contents:
Dolphins are very smart animals and
can be trained to rescue lost aquanauts.
When the dolphin reaches the
aquanaut, it guides him back to the
sea house and safety.
Dolphins can
also carry messages or mail from the
surface to the sea house
and back or
from one sea house to another.
15

Contents:
Sometimes the dolphin delivers tools
to a working aquanaut
or goes to find
things that have fallen to the ocean
floor.
Dolphins are friendly and work
well with people.
16

Contents:
Living in the sea house for many days,
the aquanauts need oxygen.
Many extra
tanks of special air containing oxygen
are taken down with them.
And so
people no longer have to guess what is
far beneath the surface of the ocean.
They can know because of the men
who go down there to find out.
17

Contents:
As more and more is learned about
the world beneath the ocean’s surface,
men are looking for new ways to use
this hidden treasure land.
There are
treasures in metals and oil to be found.
And there are many new kinds of
foods to be harvested.
18
